sen.j: 截金を工芸作品として屏風（びょうぶ）、額（がく）、衝立（ついたて）、茶入れや飾箱に応用し、東京・赤坂 (東京都港区)の迎賓館へ四曲一双屏風「霞文（かすみもん）」を納入するなど工芸分野としての基盤を築いた。
sen.e: He applied kirikane to byobu (folding screen), gaku (frame), tsuitate (one-panel screen), chaire (tea container) and kazaribako (ornamental box) as craft works and delivered a yonkyoku-isso byobu (four-panel folding screen) 'Kasumi-mon' to Geihinkan (the State Guest Houses) in Akasaka, Tokyo (Minato Ward, Tokyo Prefecture) and laid the foundations for kirikane as a category of crafts.

sen.j: 特に屏風や額などの平面な作品に截金を施す際、海の中に生息する魚や海草、薄の穂、牡丹・紫陽花・菊・椿の華を写実的に表現したという点において彼の作風が際立っている。
sen.e: His style was distinctive in that he realistically depicted fishes and seaweeds in the sea, ears of Japanese pampas grass, flowers of Botan (peonies), Ajisai (hydrangeas), Kiku (chrysanthemums) and Tsubaki (camellias) especially when he put kirikane on flat-surface works such as byobu (folding screen) or gaku (frame.)
